Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i learned how to approach ceramics from an archaeological perspective

The course offered a wide ranging approach that allowed me to understand archaeological methods of study while also learning about cultures across space and time. I also considerably developed skills for reading scientific articles and literature, a skill that will add greatly to my career path.

Knowledge of how archaeological research is conducted, the general study of archaeology, archaeological procedures, and understanding of concepts such as specialization, standardization, vessel form, shape, etc. Deriving vessel function from visual appearance. Writing research papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The professor is fabulous. She is extremely intelligent, provided thoughtful feedback on assignments, and brought in really interesting examples from her own research.

Weakness: The class structure made it difficult to engage with the topics at hand. Not sure if the structure was modified as a result of COVID, but it was all student-led discussions based on readings. If you read the readings, then class time felt kind of useless.

*Strengths: - Excellent professor and Teaching Fellow who were extremely kind, welcoming, and knowledgable. I really felt like they cared not only about the   subject matter, but also the students.
- Interesting subject matter that was as broad or as in-depth as the students wanted to get out of it.
- Interesting and engaging discussions about readings, made even more interesting by the fact that the class was composed of both undergrads and grad students, with different interests and backgrounds within Archaeology.
- Accessible for students with any level of Archaeology experience (for reference, I had nothing but a passing interest in archaeology when beginning this course, and loved it).
- Great variation of class activities and assignments; mostly discussions during class, but also presentations from the professor and TF, videos, student presentations, guest professors, etc. Also really fun and engaging assignments that were adapted to a virtual environment: virtual or COVID-safe viewing of artifacts from the Peabody, and virtual or COVID-safe pottery demonstrations, with project(s) and papers that connected to these activities. 1 project and 2 papers, all of which were interesting and different!
- Students led discussions each class, which was great!
- Assignment deadlines were manageable and explicitly respected the break days so that we didn't have extra work on days that were supposed to be break days.

*Weaknesses: - The only thing I can think of is that sometimes the readings were extremely long, but I suppose that's because it's a seminar that only meets once a week.

The focus on discussion and having the chance to exchange so many ideas is definitely a wonderful  strength of the course. 
However, I think the course could benefit from having less readings to discuss from 5 to perhaps 3 or 4. This way, we could have more time to better go through each reading, and also to discuss all the readings in class without running out of time.
It would also be great to have more time for the presentations given by the Professor and TF in some classes, as those were always very enriching.

Strengths: Fascinating content, incredible professor and TF. 
Weaknesses: A lot of reading (felt a little unmanageable)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i think it was great given the circumstances

This is a class that I imagine was quite difficult to adapt to be online, because archaeological ceramics is a physically-oriented subject, but it was adapted excellently. Instead of the in-person pottery making and demonstrations of previous years, we watched videos in class and also had virtual or COVID-safe pottery demonstrations. We were also able to view artifacts at the Peabody: through the digitized database, on a Zoom call through a fancy camera at the Peabody, and/or COVID-safe in-person.
Splitting up the already relatively small class into two breakout groups allowed for even further proximity and discussions like in a seminar setting.
The virtual lecture once a week was perfect for establishing community and maintaining the closest thing to normal lecture format. enjoyed the break out rooms, met a lot of amazing peers.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to people interested in learning in-depth about ceramics. Otherwise, this class may not be for you.
yes it was very interesting and i learned a lot
Yes! You should probably be interested in archaeology or ceramics/pottery, because it'd a very narrowed down subject, but I only had a passing interest in archaeology and LOVED it!
Definitely, especially to anyone who has any interest in exploring the subject.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were a few optional in-person activities.
